class Button(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class Button(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents a clickable button UI element for SUILib applications.
 44
 45    The Button displays customizable text, supports style configuration,
 46    and triggers a callback function when clicked. It handles rendering
 47    with hover and selection effects, and automatically adjusts its size
 48    to fit the text content.
 49
 50    Attributes:
 51        text (str): The text displayed on the button.
 52        callback (callable): Function to be called when the button is clicked.
 53        hover (bool): Indicates whether the button is currently hovered.
 54        font (pygame.font.Font): Font object used for rendering button text.
 55    """
 56
 57    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, text: str, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 58        """
 59        Initialize a new Button instance.
 60
 61        Args:
 62            view: The parent View instance where this button is placed.
 63            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the button.
 64                See config/styles.json for details.
 65            text (str): The text to display on the button.
 66            width (int, optional): Width of the button in pixels. Defaults to 0 (auto).
 67            height (int, optional): Height of the button in pixels. Defaults to 0 (auto).
 68            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the button. Defaults to 0.
 69            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the button. Defaults to 0.
 70        """
 71        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
 72        self.text = text
 73        self.callback = None
 74        self.hover = False
 75        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
 76            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
 77            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
 78            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
 79        )
 80
 81    def setText(self, text: str):
 82        """
 83        Set the button's display text.
 84
 85        Args:
 86            text (str): New text to display on the button.
 87        """
 88        self.text = text
 89
 90    def getText(self) -> str:
 91        """
 92        Get the current text displayed on the button.
 93
 94        Returns:
 95            str: The button's display text.
 96        """
 97        return self.text
 98
 99    def setClickEvt(self, callback):
100        """
101        Set the callback function to be called when the button is clicked.
102
103        Args:
104            callback (callable): Function to be invoked on click event.
105                The function should accept a single argument: the Button instance.
106        """
107        self.callback = callback
108
109    @overrides(GUIElement)
110    def draw(self, view, screen):
111        """
112        Draw the button on the given screen surface.
113
114        Args:
115            view: The parent View instance.
116            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the button onto.
117        """
118        # Draw button background with selection effect
119        if self.isSelected():
120            c = super().getStyle()["background_color"]
121            pygame.draw.rect(
122                screen,
123                colorChange(c, -0.2 if c[0] > 128 else 0.6),
124                super().getViewRect(),
125                border_radius=10
126            )
127        else:
128            pygame.draw.rect(
129                screen,
130                super().getStyle()["background_color"],
131                super().getViewRect(),
132                border_radius=10
133            )
134        # Draw button text
135        if len(self.text) != 0:
136            text_surface = self.font.render(
137                self.text, True, super().getStyle()["foreground_color"]
138            )
139            # Auto-resize button to fit text if needed
140            if text_surface.get_height() + 4 > super().getHeight():
141                super().setHeight(text_surface.get_height() + 4)
142            if text_surface.get_width() + 4 > super().getWidth():
143                super().setWidth(text_surface.get_width() + 4)
144            screen.blit(
145                text_surface,
146                (
147                    super().getX() + (super().getWidth() - text_surface.get_width()) / 2,
148                    super().getY() + (super().getHeight() - text_surface.get_height()) / 2
149                )
150            )
151        # Draw button outline
152        pygame.draw.rect(
153            screen,
154            super().getStyle()["outline_color"],
155            super().getViewRect(),
156            2,
157            border_radius=10
158        )
159
160    @overrides(GUIElement)
161    def processEvent(self, view, event):
162        """
163        Process a Pygame event related to the button.
164
165        Handles mouse button down and mouse motion events to manage
166        selection/hover state and trigger the click callback.
167
168        Args:
169            view: The parent View instance.
170            event (pygame.event.Event): The Pygame event to process.
171        """
172        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
173            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
174                if self.callback is not None:
175                    self.callback(self)
176        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEMOTION:
177            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
178                self.select()
179            else:
180                self.unSelect()
181
182    @overrides(GUIElement)
183    def update(self, view):
184        """
185        Update logic for the button.
186
187        This method is a placeholder for future extensions;
188        currently, it does not perform any updates.
189
190        Args:
191            view: The parent View instance.
192        """
193        pass

Represents a clickable button UI element for SUILib applications.

The Button displays customizable text, supports style configuration, and triggers a callback function when clicked. It handles rendering with hover and selection effects, and automatically adjusts its size to fit the text content.

Attributes:
  • text (str): The text displayed on the button.
  • callback (callable): Function to be called when the button is clicked.
  • hover (bool): Indicates whether the button is currently hovered.
  • font (pygame.font.Font): Font object used for rendering button text.
Button( view, style: dict, text: str, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0)

62            view: The parent View instance where this button is placed.

64                See config/styles.json for details.
65            text (str): The text to display on the button.
66            width (int, optional): Width of the button in pixels. Defaults to 0 (auto).
67            height (int, optional): Height of the button in pixels. Defaults to 0 (auto).
68            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the button. Defaults to 0.
69            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the button. Defaults to 0.
70        """
71        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
72        self.text = text
73        self.callback = None
74        self.hover = False
75        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
76            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
77            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
78            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
79        )

class Canvas(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class Canvas(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents a drawable canvas UI element for custom rendering and mouse-interactive content.
 44
 45    The Canvas provides an area within the UI where custom graphics can be drawn, either
 46    statically or dynamically. It supports mouse interaction for controlling the drawing
 47    offset (useful for panning or other transformations), and allows the user to define a
 48    paint callback for custom content rendering.
 49
 50    Attributes:
 51        callback (callable): Paint callback function for custom drawing.
 52        control (bool): Whether mouse control (panning) is enabled.
 53        mouse_sensitivity (float): Adjusts the responsiveness of mouse movement.
 54        offset (list): Current drawing offset [x, y].
 55        font (pygame.font.Font): Font used for any text rendering inside the canvas.
 56    """
 57
 58    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 59        """
 60        Initialize a new Canvas instance.
 61
 62        Args:
 63            view: The parent View instance where this canvas is placed.
 64            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the canvas.
 65                See config/styles.json for details.
 66            width (int, optional): Width of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 67            height (int, optional): Height of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 68            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.
 69            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.
 70        """
 71        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style, pygame.SYSTEM_CURSOR_SIZEALL)
 72        self.callback = None
 73        self.control = False
 74        self.mouse_sensitivity = 2.0
 75        self.offset = [0, 0]
 76        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
 77            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
 78            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
 79            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
 80        )
 81
 82    def enableMouseControl(self):
 83        """
 84        Enable mouse control for the canvas.
 85
 86        When enabled, mouse drag events within the canvas area can be used to modify
 87        the drawing offset (e.g., for panning or rotating the content).
 88        """
 89        self.control = True
 90
 91    def disableMouseControl(self):
 92        """
 93        Disable mouse control for the canvas.
 94
 95        When disabled, mouse events will not affect the drawing offset or transformations.
 96        """
 97        self.control = False
 98
 99    def setMouseSensitivity(self, mouse_sensitivity: float):
100        """
101        Set the sensitivity for mouse-based canvas control.
102
103        Args:
104            mouse_sensitivity (float): Multiplier for how much the offset changes per pixel moved.
105        """
106        self.mouse_sensitivity = mouse_sensitivity
107
108    def getMouseSensitivity(self) -> float:
109        """
110        Get the current mouse sensitivity value.
111
112        Returns:
113            float: The mouse sensitivity multiplier.
114        """
115        return self.mouse_sensitivity
116
117    def setOffset(self, offset: list):
118        """
119        Set the drawing offset for the canvas.
120
121        Args:
122            offset (list): List of two values [x, y] representing the offset.
123        """
124        self.offset = offset
125
126    def getOffset(self) -> list:
127        """
128        Get the current drawing offset.
129
130        Returns:
131            list: The current offset [x, y].
132        """
133        return self.offset
134
135    def setPaintEvt(self, callback):
136        """
137        Set the paint event callback for the canvas.
138
139        The callback should be a function accepting (surface, offset) and will be called
140        whenever the canvas needs to be redrawn.
141
142        Args:
143            callback (callable): Function to be called for custom drawing.
144        """
145        self.callback = callback
146
147    @overrides(GUIElement)
148    def draw(self, view, screen):
149        """
150        Render the canvas and call the user-provided paint callback.
151
152        Args:
153            view: The parent View instance.
154            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the canvas onto.
155        """
156        # Draw canvas background
157        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect())
158
159        # Create a subsurface for drawing
160        surface = screen.subsurface(
161            pygame.Rect(
162                super().getX(),
163                super().getY(),
164                min(max(super().getWidth(), 10), screen.get_width() - super().getX()),
165                min(max(super().getHeight(), 10), screen.get_height() - super().getY())
166            )
167        )
168        # Call the paint callback if set
169        if self.callback is not None:
170            self.callback(surface, self.offset)
171
172        # Draw canvas outline
173        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2)
174
175    @overrides(GUIElement)
176    def processEvent(self, view, event):
177        """
178        Process Pygame events for mouse-based canvas interaction.
179
180        Args:
181            view: The parent View instance.
182            event (pygame.event.Event): The Pygame event to process.
183        """
184        if self.control:
185            if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
186                if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
187                    super().select()
188                    self.mouse_motion = True
189            elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP:
190                super().unSelect()
191            elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEMOTION:
192                if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
193                    if self.isSelected():
194                        if self.mouse_motion:
195                            self.last_pos = event.pos
196                        else:
197                            self.offset[0] += (event.pos[0] - self.last_pos[0]) * self.mouse_sensitivity
198                            self.offset[1] += (event.pos[1] - self.last_pos[1]) * self.mouse_sensitivity
199                        self.mouse_motion = not self.mouse_motion
200

202    def update(self, view):

207        currently, it does not perform any updates.

Represents a drawable canvas UI element for custom rendering and mouse-interactive content.

The Canvas provides an area within the UI where custom graphics can be drawn, either statically or dynamically. It supports mouse interaction for controlling the drawing offset (useful for panning or other transformations), and allows the user to define a paint callback for custom content rendering.

Attributes:
  • callback (callable): Paint callback function for custom drawing.
  • control (bool): Whether mouse control (panning) is enabled.
  • mouse_sensitivity (float): Adjusts the responsiveness of mouse movement.
  • offset (list): Current drawing offset [x, y].
  • font (pygame.font.Font): Font used for any text rendering inside the canvas.
Canvas( view, style: dict, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0) 
58    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
59        """
60        Initialize a new Canvas instance.
61
62        Args:
63            view: The parent View instance where this canvas is placed.
64            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the canvas.
65                See config/styles.json for details.
66            width (int, optional): Width of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
67            height (int, optional): Height of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
68            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.
69            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.
70        """
71        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style, pygame.SYSTEM_CURSOR_SIZEALL)
72        self.callback = None
73        self.control = False
74        self.mouse_sensitivity = 2.0
75        self.offset = [0, 0]
76        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
77            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
78            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
79            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
80        )

  • width (int, optional): Width of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
  • height (int, optional): Height of the canvas in pixels. Defaults to 0.
  • x (int, optional): X coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.
  • y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the canvas. Defaults to 0.

@overrides(GUIElement)
def draw(self, view, screen): 
147    @overrides(GUIElement)
148    def draw(self, view, screen):
149        """
150        Render the canvas and call the user-provided paint callback.
151
152        Args:
153            view: The parent View instance.
154            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the canvas onto.
155        """
156        # Draw canvas background
157        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect())
158
159        # Create a subsurface for drawing
160        surface = screen.subsurface(
161            pygame.Rect(
162                super().getX(),
163                super().getY(),
164                min(max(super().getWidth(), 10), screen.get_width() - super().getX()),
165                min(max(super().getHeight(), 10), screen.get_height() - super().getY())
166            )
167        )
168        # Call the paint callback if set
169        if self.callback is not None:
170            self.callback(surface, self.offset)
171
172        # Draw canvas outline
173        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2)

class CheckBox(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 42class CheckBox(GUIElement):
 43    """
 44    Represents a checkbox UI element with a label for SUILib applications.
 45
 46    The CheckBox allows users to toggle a boolean state (checked/unchecked) and displays
 47    an associated label. It supports custom styles, click event callbacks, and integrates
 48    seamlessly within the View layout system.
 49
 50    Attributes:
 51        label (Label): The label displayed next to the checkbox.
 52        checked (bool): Indicates whether the checkbox is checked.
 53        callback (callable): Function to be called when the checkbox state changes.
 54    """
 55
 56    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, text: str, checked: bool, size: int = 20, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 57        """
 58        Initialize a new CheckBox instance.
 59
 60        Args:
 61            view: The parent View instance where this checkbox is placed.
 62            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the checkbox.
 63                See config/styles.json for details.
 64            text (str): Text to display as the checkbox label.
 65            checked (bool): Initial checked state of the checkbox.
 66            size (int, optional): Width and height of the checkbox square in pixels. Defaults to 20.
 67            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the checkbox. Defaults to 0.
 68            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the checkbox. Defaults to 0.
 69        """
 70        super().__init__(view, x, y, size, size, style)
 71        self.label = Label(view, super().getStyle()["label"], text, False, True, x, y)
 72        self.checked = checked
 73        self.callback = None
 74
 75    def setText(self, text: str):
 76        """
 77        Set the text of the checkbox label.
 78
 79        Args:
 80            text (str): New label text.
 81        """
 82        if self.label is not None:
 83            self.label.setText(text)
 84
 85    def getLabel(self) -> Label:
 86        """
 87        Get the label object associated with this checkbox.
 88
 89        Returns:
 90            Label: The label instance.
 91        """
 92        return self.label
 93
 94    def setCheckedEvt(self, callback):
 95        """
 96        Set the callback function to be called when the checked state changes.
 97
 98        Args:
 99            callback (callable): Function to be invoked on check/uncheck.
100                The function should accept a single argument: the CheckBox instance.
101        """
102        self.callback = callback
103
104    def setChecked(self, checked: bool):
105        """
106        Set the checked state of this checkbox.
107
108        Args:
109            checked (bool): True if the checkbox should be checked, False otherwise.
110        """
111        self.checked = checked
112
113    def isChecked(self) -> bool:
114        """
115        Return whether this checkbox is currently checked.
116
117        Returns:
118            bool: True if checked, False otherwise.
119        """
120        return self.checked
121
122    @overrides(GUIElement)
123    def draw(self, view, screen):
124        """
125        Render the checkbox and its label onto the provided surface.
126
127        Args:
128            view: The parent View instance.
129            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the checkbox onto.
130        """
131        # Position and draw the label
132        if self.label is not None:
133            self.label.setX(super().getX() + super().getWidth() + 5)
134            self.label.setY(super().getY() + super().getHeight() / 2)
135            self.label.draw(view, screen)
136        # Draw checkbox background
137        if super().isSelected():
138            c = super().getStyle()["background_color"]
139            pygame.draw.rect(
140                screen,
141                colorChange(c, -0.2 if c[0] > 128 else 0.6),
142                super().getViewRect(),
143                border_radius=6
144            )
145        else:
146            pygame.draw.rect(
147                screen,
148                super().getStyle()["background_color"],
149                super().getViewRect(),
150                border_radius=5
151            )
152        # Draw checkbox outline
153        pygame.draw.rect(
154            screen,
155            super().getStyle()["outline_color"],
156            super().getViewRect(),
157            2,
158            border_radius=5
159        )
160        # Draw checkmark if checked
161        if self.checked:
162            pts = [
163                (super().getX() + super().getWidth() * 0.2, super().getY() + super().getWidth() * 0.5),
164                (super().getX() + super().getWidth() * 0.4, super().getY() + super().getWidth() * 0.75),
165                (super().getX() + super().getWidth() * 0.8, super().getY() + super().getWidth() * 0.2)
166            ]
167            pygame.draw.lines(
168                screen,
169                super().getStyle()["foreground_color"],
170                False,
171                pts,
172                round(7 * super().getWidth() / 40)
173            )
174
175    @overrides(GUIElement)
176    def processEvent(self, view, event):
177        """
178        Handle Pygame events for checkbox interaction (click, hover).
179
180        Args:
181            view: The parent View instance.
182            event (pygame.event.Event): The Pygame event to process.
183        """
184        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
185            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
186                if self.callback is not None:
187                    self.callback(self)
188                self.checked = not self.checked
189        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEMOTION:
190            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
191                super().select()
192            else:
193                super().unSelect()
194
195    @overrides(GUIElement)
196    def update(self, view):
197        """
198        Update logic for the checkbox.
199
200        This method is a placeholder for future extensions; currently, it does not perform any updates.
201
202        Args:
203            view: The parent View instance.
204        """
205        pass

class ComboBox(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement, SUILib.guielement.Container): 
 43class ComboBox(GUIElement, Container):
 44    """
 45    Represents a dropdown ComboBox UI element for SUILib applications.
 46
 47    ComboBox allows users to select a value from a list of options via a dropdown menu.
 48    It combines a display area showing the current selection and a button that toggles
 49    the visibility of a popup panel containing all available options. ComboBox supports
 50    customizable styles, value change callbacks, and integrates with the View layout system.
 51
 52    Attributes:
 53        values (list): List of selectable string options.
 54        selected_item (str): Currently selected value.
 55        button (Button): The dropdown toggle button.
 56        listpanel (ListPanel): The popup panel displaying selectable options.
 57        callback (callable): Function to be called when the selected value changes.
 58        font (pygame.font.Font): Font used for rendering the selected value.
 59    """
 60
 61    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, values: list, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 62        """
 63        Initialize a new ComboBox instance.
 64
 65        Args:
 66            view: The parent View instance where this ComboBox is placed.
 67            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the ComboBox.
 68                See config/styles.json for details.
 69            values (list): List of string values to choose from.
 70            width (int, optional): Width of the ComboBox in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 71            height (int, optional): Height of the ComboBox in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 72            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the ComboBox. Defaults to 0.
 73            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the ComboBox. Defaults to 0.
 74        """
 75        self.button = None
 76        self.listpanel = None
 77        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
 78        self.values = values
 79        self.callback = None
 80        self.hover = False
 81        self.selected_item = values[0]
 82        # Popup panel for options
 83        self.listpanel = ListPanel(
 84            view, super().getStyle()["listpanel"], values)
 85        self.listpanel.setVisibility(False)
 86        self.listpanel.setItemClickEvet(lambda p: self.setSelectedItem(p))
 87        # Dropdown toggle button
 88        self.button = Button(view, super().getStyle()["button"], "↓")
 89        self.button.setClickEvt(
 90            lambda x: self.setPopupPanelVisibility(not self.listpanel.isVisible()))
 91        # Font for rendering selected value
 92        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
 93            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
 94            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
 95            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
 96        )
 97        super().updateViewRect()
 98
 99    @overrides(GUIElement)
100    def updateViewRect(self):
101        """
102        Update the ComboBox's view rectangle and synchronize the position and size
103        of the button and popup panel with the ComboBox dimensions.
104        """
105        super().updateViewRect()
106        if self.button is not None:
107            self.button.setWidth(super().getHeight())
108            self.button.setHeight(super().getHeight())
109            self.button.setX(super().getX() + super().getWidth() - self.button.getWidth())
110            self.button.setY(super().getY())
111        if self.listpanel is not None:
112            self.listpanel.setWidth(super().getWidth())
113            self.listpanel.setX(super().getX())
114            self.listpanel.setY(super().getY() + super().getHeight())
115
116    def setPopupPanelVisibility(self, visibility):
117        """
118        Set the visibility of the popup panel containing selectable options.
119
120        Args:
121            visibility (bool): True to show the panel, False to hide it.
122        """
123        self.listpanel.setVisibility(visibility)
124        if self.listpanel.isVisible():
125            self.getView().setFilter_processOnly(self)
126            self.button.setText("↑")
127        else:
128            self.button.setText("↓")
129            self.getView().clearFilter()
130
131    def setValues(self, values: list):
132        """
133        Set the list of possible values for the ComboBox.
134
135        Args:
136            values (list): The new list of selectable options.
137        """
138        self.values = values
139
140    def getValues(self) -> list:
141        """
142        Get the list of possible values for the ComboBox.
143
144        Returns:
145            list: The current list of selectable options.
146        """
147        return self.values
148
149    def getSelectedItem(self) -> str:
150        """
151        Get the currently selected item.
152
153        Returns:
154            str: The currently selected option.
155        """
156        return self.selected_item
157
158    def setSelectedItem(self, item_name: str):
159        """
160        Set the currently selected item and hide the popup panel.
161
162        Args:
163            item_name (str): The value to select.
164        """
165        self.selected_item = item_name
166        self.setPopupPanelVisibility(False)
167        if self.callback is not None:
168            self.callback(self.selected_item)
169
170    def setValueChangedEvt(self, callback):
171        """
172        Set the callback function to be called when the selected value changes.
173
174        Args:
175            callback (callable): Function to be invoked on value change.
176                The function should accept a single argument: the selected item (str).
177        """
178        self.callback = callback
179
180    @overrides(GUIElement)
181    def draw(self, view, screen):
182        """
183        Render the ComboBox, including the display area, button, and popup panel if visible.
184
185        Args:
186            view: The parent View instance.
187            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the ComboBox onto.
188        """
189        # Draw ComboBox background
190        if self.isSelected():
191            c = super().getStyle()["background_color"]
192            pygame.draw.rect(screen, colorChange(
193                c, -0.2 if c[0] > 128 else 0.6), super().getViewRect(), border_radius=10)
194        else:
195            pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect(), border_radius=10)
196        # Draw selected value text
197        if len(self.values[0]) != 0:
198            screen.set_clip(super().getViewRect())
199            text = self.font.render(
200                self.selected_item,
201                1,
202                super().getStyle()["foreground_color"]
203            )
204            screen.blit(
205                text,
206                (
207                    super().getX() + (super().getWidth() - text.get_width())/2,
208                    super().getY() + (super().getHeight() - text.get_height())/2
209                )
210            )
211            screen.set_clip(None)
212        # Draw ComboBox outline
213        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2, border_radius=10)
214        # Draw dropdown button
215        self.button.draw(view, screen)
216        # Draw popup panel if visible (on top)
217        if self.listpanel.isVisible():
218            self.getView().getApp().drawLater(1000, self.listpanel.draw)
219
220    @overrides(GUIElement)
221    def processEvent(self, view, event):
222        """
223        Handle Pygame events for ComboBox interaction.
224
225        Args:
226            view: The parent View instance.
227            event (pygame.event.Event): The Pygame event to process.
228        """
229        self.button.processEvent(view, event)
230        if self.listpanel.isVisible():
231            self.listpanel.processEvent(view, event)
232        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
233            if not inRect(
234                event.pos[0],
235                event.pos[1],
236                pygame.Rect(
237                    super().getX(),
238                    super().getY(),
239                    super().getWidth(),
240                    super().getHeight() + self.listpanel.getHeight() + 5
241                )
242            ):
243                self.setPopupPanelVisibility(False)
244
245    @overrides(GUIElement)
246    def update(self, view):
247        """
248        Update logic for the ComboBox.
249
250        This method is a placeholder for future extensions; currently, it does not perform any updates.
251
252        Args:
253            view: The parent View instance.
254        """
255        pass
256
257    @overrides(Container)
258    def getChilds(self):
259        """
260        Return the child elements of the ComboBox.
261
262        Returns:
263            list: List containing the dropdown button as a child element.
264        """
265        return [self.button]

Represents a dropdown ComboBox UI element for SUILib applications.

ComboBox allows users to select a value from a list of options via a dropdown menu. It combines a display area showing the current selection and a button that toggles the visibility of a popup panel containing all available options. ComboBox supports customizable styles, value change callbacks, and integrates with the View layout system.

Attributes:
  • values (list): List of selectable string options.
  • selected_item (str): Currently selected value.
  • button (Button): The dropdown toggle button.
  • listpanel (ListPanel): The popup panel displaying selectable options.
  • callback (callable): Function to be called when the selected value changes.
  • font (pygame.font.Font): Font used for rendering the selected value.
ComboBox( view, style: dict, values: list, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0) 
61    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, values: list, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
62        """
63        Initialize a new ComboBox instance.
64
65        Args:
66            view: The parent View instance where this ComboBox is placed.
67            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the ComboBox.
68                See config/styles.json for details.
69            values (list): List of string values to choose from.
70            width (int, optional): Width of the ComboBox in pixels. Defaults to 0.
71            height (int, optional): Height of the ComboBox in pixels. Defaults to 0.
72            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the ComboBox. Defaults to 0.
73            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the ComboBox. Defaults to 0.
74        """
75        self.button = None
76        self.listpanel = None
77        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
78        self.values = values
79        self.callback = None
80        self.hover = False
81        self.selected_item = values[0]
82        # Popup panel for options
83        self.listpanel = ListPanel(
84            view, super().getStyle()["listpanel"], values)
85        self.listpanel.setVisibility(False)
86        self.listpanel.setItemClickEvet(lambda p: self.setSelectedItem(p))
87        # Dropdown toggle button
88        self.button = Button(view, super().getStyle()["button"], "↓")
89        self.button.setClickEvt(
90            lambda x: self.setPopupPanelVisibility(not self.listpanel.isVisible()))
91        # Font for rendering selected value
92        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
93            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
94            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
95            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
96        )
97        super().updateViewRect()

class Graph(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 40class Graph(GUIElement):
 41    """
 42    Represents a data visualization widget for displaying various types of graphs (line, bar, pie, scatter, dot) using Matplotlib and Pygame.
 43
 44    The Graph element renders a matplotlib figure into a Pygame surface, allowing dynamic graph content
 45    inside SUILib views. The user supplies a figure builder function which draws the graph using matplotlib.
 46
 47    Attributes:
 48        graph (pygame.Surface): The rendered graph as a Pygame surface.
 49        fig_builder (callable): The user-supplied function for building the matplotlib figure.
 50    """
 51
 52    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 53        """
 54        Initialize a new Graph instance.
 55
 56        Args:
 57            view: The parent View instance where this graph is placed.
 58            style (dict): Dictionary describing the style for this graph.
 59            width (int, optional): Width of the graph in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 60            height (int, optional): Height of the graph in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 61            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the graph. Defaults to 0.
 62            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the graph. Defaults to 0.
 63        """
 64        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
 65        self.graph = None
 66        self.fig_builder = None
 67
 68    def setFigureBuilderFunc(self, func):
 69        """
 70        Set the function responsible for building the matplotlib figure.
 71
 72        Args:
 73            func (callable): Builder function with signature `def builder(fig): ...`
 74                - The function receives a matplotlib.figure.Figure instance and
 75                  should draw the desired graph on it.
 76        """
 77        self.fig_builder = func
 78
 79    @overrides(GUIElement)
 80    def setWidth(self, width):
 81        """
 82        Set the width of the graph and refresh the rendered figure.
 83
 84        Args:
 85            width (int): New width in pixels.
 86        """
 87        super().setWidth(width)
 88        self.refreshGraph()
 89
 90    @overrides(GUIElement)
 91    def setHeight(self, height):
 92        """
 93        Set the height of the graph and refresh the rendered figure.
 94
 95        Args:
 96            height (int): New height in pixels.
 97        """
 98        super().setHeight(height)
 99        self.refreshGraph()
100
101    def refreshGraph(self):
102        """
103        Redraw and re-render the matplotlib figure to the Pygame surface.
104        Called automatically when the size of the graph changes or the builder function is set.
105        """
106        if self.fig_builder is not None and super().getWidth() > 50 and super().getHeight() > 50:
107            fig = pylab.figure(
108                figsize=[self.getWidth()/100, self.getHeight()/100], dpi=100)
109            fig.patch.set_alpha(0.0)
110            self.fig_builder(fig)
111            self.graph = drawGraph(
112                fig,
113                super().getStyle()["theme"]
114            )
115
116    @overrides(GUIElement)
117    def draw(self, view, screen):
118        """
119        Render the graph onto the given Pygame surface.
120
121        Args:
122            view: The parent View instance.
123            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the graph onto.
124        """
125        if self.graph is not None:
126            screen.blit(
127                pygame.transform.scale(self.graph, (super().getWidth(), super().getHeight())),
128                (super().getX(), super().getY())
129            )
130
131    @overrides(GUIElement)
132    def processEvent(self, view, event):
133        """
134        Handle Pygame events for the graph.
135
136        Args:
137            view: The parent View instance.
138            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
139        """
140        pass
141
142    @overrides(GUIElement)
143    def update(self, view):
144        """
145        Update logic for the graph.
146
147        Args:
148            view: The parent View instance.
149        """
150        pass
151
152    @staticmethod
153    def builderFunc_lineGraph(fig, x_label, y_label, values, legend=None):
154        """
155        Builder function for Graph: Plot line graph.
156
157        Args:
158            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
159            x_label (str): Label for X axis.
160            y_label (str): Label for Y axis.
161            values (list): List of lists, each representing Y values of a line.
162            legend (list, optional): List of legend strings.
163
164        Example:
165            Graph.builderFunc_lineGraph(
166                f,
167                "X axis",
168                "Y axis",
169                [[1, 2, 3, 4], [2, 4, 10, 8], [3, 7, 17, 12]],
170                ['A', 'B', 'C']
171            )
172        """
173        ax = fig.gca()
174        for i, line in enumerate(values):
175            line_plot, = ax.plot(line)
176            if legend and i < len(legend):
177                line_plot.set_label(legend[i])
178                ax.legend()
179        ax.set_xlabel(x_label)
180        ax.set_ylabel(y_label)
181
182    @staticmethod
183    def builderFunc_pieGraph(fig, labels, values, explode=None):
184        """
185        Builder function for Graph: Plot pie graph.
186
187        Args:
188            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
189            labels (list): Labels for the pie sections.
190            values (list): Values for each section.
191            explode (list, optional): Offsets for each section.
192
193        Example:
194            Graph.builderFunc_pieGraph(
195                f,
196                ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
197                [1, 2, 3, 5],
198                (0, 0.2, 0, 0)
199            )
200        """
201        ax = fig.gca()
202        ax.pie(values, explode=explode, labels=labels, autopct='%1.1f%%',
203               shadow=True, startangle=90)
204        ax.axis('equal')
205
206    @staticmethod
207    def builderFunc_dotGraph(fig, x_label, y_label, values, legend=None):
208        """
209        Builder function for Graph: Dot graph.
210
211        Args:
212            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
213            x_label (str): Label for X axis.
214            y_label (str): Label for Y axis.
215            values (list): List of lists, each representing Y values of a line.
216            legend (list, optional): List of legend strings.
217
218        Example:
219            Graph.builderFunc_dotGraph(
220                f,
221                "X axis",
222                "Y axis",
223                [[1, 2, 3, 4], [2, 4, 10, 8], [3, 7, 17, 12]],
224                ['A', 'B', 'C']
225            )
226        """
227        ax = fig.gca()
228        for i, line in enumerate(values):
229            line_plot, = ax.plot(line, '.')
230            if legend and i < len(legend):
231                line_plot.set_label(legend[i])
232                ax.legend()
233        ax.set_xlabel(x_label)
234        ax.set_ylabel(y_label)
235
236    @staticmethod
237    def builderFunc_barGraph(fig, labels, values):
238        """
239        Builder function for Graph: Bar graph.
240
241        Args:
242            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
243            labels (list): Labels for bars.
244            values (list): Values for each bar.
245
246        Example:
247            Graph.builderFunc_barGraph(
248                f,
249                ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],
250                [2, 4, 10, 8]
251            )
252        """
253        ax = fig.gca()
254        ax.bar(labels, values, width=1, edgecolor="white", linewidth=0.7)
255
256    @staticmethod
257    def builderFunc_scatterGraph(fig, values, xlim, ylim):
258        """
259        Builder function for Graph: Scatter graph.
260
261        Args:
262            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
263            values (list): List of (x, y) tuples for each point.
264            xlim (tuple): (min, max) for x axis.
265            ylim (tuple): (min, max) for y axis.
266
267        Example:
268            Graph.builderFunc_scatterGraph(
269                f,
270                [(1, 2), (4, 5), (4, 7), (6, 1), (4, 3)],
271                (0, 8),
272                (0, 8)
273            )
274        """
275        ax = fig.gca()
276        x = [pt[0] for pt in values]
277        y = [pt[1] for pt in values]
278        sizes = np.random.uniform(15, 80, len(x))
279        colors = np.random.uniform(15, 80, len(x))
280        ax.scatter(x, y, s=sizes, c=colors, vmin=0, vmax=100)
281        ax.set(xlim=xlim, ylim=ylim)

Represents a data visualization widget for displaying various types of graphs (line, bar, pie, scatter, dot) using Matplotlib and Pygame.

The Graph element renders a matplotlib figure into a Pygame surface, allowing dynamic graph content inside SUILib views. The user supplies a figure builder function which draws the graph using matplotlib.

Attributes:
  • graph (pygame.Surface): The rendered graph as a Pygame surface.
  • fig_builder (callable): The user-supplied function for building the matplotlib figure.

def refreshGraph(self): 
101    def refreshGraph(self):
102        """
103        Redraw and re-render the matplotlib figure to the Pygame surface.
104        Called automatically when the size of the graph changes or the builder function is set.
105        """
106        if self.fig_builder is not None and super().getWidth() > 50 and super().getHeight() > 50:
107            fig = pylab.figure(
108                figsize=[self.getWidth()/100, self.getHeight()/100], dpi=100)
109            fig.patch.set_alpha(0.0)
110            self.fig_builder(fig)
111            self.graph = drawGraph(
112                fig,
113                super().getStyle()["theme"]
114            )

Redraw and re-render the matplotlib figure to the Pygame surface. Called automatically when the size of the graph changes or the builder function is set.

@staticmethod
def builderFunc_lineGraph(fig, x_label, y_label, values, legend=None): 
152    @staticmethod
153    def builderFunc_lineGraph(fig, x_label, y_label, values, legend=None):
154        """
155        Builder function for Graph: Plot line graph.
156
157        Args:
158            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
159            x_label (str): Label for X axis.
160            y_label (str): Label for Y axis.
161            values (list): List of lists, each representing Y values of a line.
162            legend (list, optional): List of legend strings.
163
164        Example:
165            Graph.builderFunc_lineGraph(
166                f,
167                "X axis",
168                "Y axis",
169                [[1, 2, 3, 4], [2, 4, 10, 8], [3, 7, 17, 12]],
170                ['A', 'B', 'C']
171            )
172        """
173        ax = fig.gca()
174        for i, line in enumerate(values):
175            line_plot, = ax.plot(line)
176            if legend and i < len(legend):
177                line_plot.set_label(legend[i])
178                ax.legend()
179        ax.set_xlabel(x_label)
180        ax.set_ylabel(y_label)

Builder function for Graph: Plot line graph.

Arguments:
  • fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
  • x_label (str): Label for X axis.
  • y_label (str): Label for Y axis.
  • values (list): List of lists, each representing Y values of a line.
  • legend (list, optional): List of legend strings.
Example:

Graph.builderFunc_lineGraph( f, "X axis", "Y axis", [[1, 2, 3, 4], [2, 4, 10, 8], [3, 7, 17, 12]], ['A', 'B', 'C'] )

@staticmethod
def builderFunc_pieGraph(fig, labels, values, explode=None):

185        Builder function for Graph: Plot pie graph.

196                ['A', 'B', 'C', 'D'],

@staticmethod
def builderFunc_scatterGraph(fig, values, xlim, ylim): 
256    @staticmethod
257    def builderFunc_scatterGraph(fig, values, xlim, ylim):
258        """
259        Builder function for Graph: Scatter graph.
260
261        Args:
262            fig: The matplotlib Figure object to plot on.
263            values (list): List of (x, y) tuples for each point.
264            xlim (tuple): (min, max) for x axis.
265            ylim (tuple): (min, max) for y axis.
266
267        Example:
268            Graph.builderFunc_scatterGraph(
269                f,

272                (0, 8)
273            )
274        """
275        ax = fig.gca()
276        x = [pt[0] for pt in values]
277        y = [pt[1] for pt in values]
278        sizes = np.random.uniform(15, 80, len(x))
279        colors = np.random.uniform(15, 80, len(x))
280        ax.scatter(x, y, s=sizes, c=colors, vmin=0, vmax=100)
281        ax.set(xlim=xlim, ylim=ylim)

class HorizontalScrollbar(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class HorizontalScrollbar(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents a horizontal scrollbar UI element for SUILib applications.
 44
 45    The HorizontalScrollbar allows users to select or scroll through a range horizontally.
 46    It supports custom styles, drag interaction, and a callback for scroll events.
 47
 48    Attributes:
 49        callback (callable): Function to be called when the scrollbar moves.
 50        scroller_pos (int): Current X position (in pixels) of the scroller.
 51        scroller_size (int): Width of the draggable scroller in pixels.
 52    """
 53
 54    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, scroller_size: int, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 55        """
 56        Initialize a new HorizontalScrollbar instance.
 57
 58        Args:
 59            view: The parent View instance where this scrollbar is placed.
 60            style (dict): Dictionary describing the style for this scrollbar.
 61                See config/styles.json for details.
 62            scroller_size (int): Width of the draggable scroller in pixels.
 63            width (int, optional): Width of the scrollbar in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 64            height (int, optional): Height of the scrollbar in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 65            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the scrollbar. Defaults to 0.
 66            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the scrollbar. Defaults to 0.
 67        """
 68        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style, pygame.SYSTEM_CURSOR_SIZEWE)
 69        self.callback = None
 70        self.scroller_pos = 0
 71        self.scroller_size = scroller_size
 72
 73    def setScrollerSize(self, size: int):
 74        """
 75        Set the width of the scroller.
 76
 77        Args:
 78            size (int): New width of the scroller in pixels.
 79        """
 80        self.scroller_size = max(size, super().getHeight())
 81
 82    def setOnScrollEvt(self, callback):
 83        """
 84        Set the callback function to be called when the scrollbar position changes.
 85
 86        Args:
 87            callback (callable): Function to be invoked on scroll.
 88                The function should accept the normalized scroll position (float from 0.0 to 1.0).
 89        """
 90        self.callback = callback
 91
 92    @overrides(GUIElement)
 93    def draw(self, view, screen):
 94        """
 95        Render the horizontal scrollbar and its scroller.
 96
 97        Args:
 98            view: The parent View instance.
 99            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the scrollbar onto.
100        """
101        # Draw background
102        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect())
103        # Draw scroller
104        pygame.draw.rect(
105            screen,
106            super().getStyle()["foreground_color"],
107            pygame.Rect(
108                super().getX() + self.scroller_pos,
109                super().getY(),
110                self.scroller_size,
111                super().getHeight()
112            ),
113            border_radius=6
114        )
115        # Draw outline
116        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2)
117
118    @overrides(GUIElement)
119    def processEvent(self, view, event):
120        """
121        Handle Pygame events for scrollbar interaction (drag, release, hover).
122
123        Args:
124            view: The parent View instance.
125            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
126        """
127        if self.scroller_size >= super().getWidth():
128            return
129        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
130            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
131                super().select()
132                self.def_scroller_pos = self.scroller_pos
133                self.drag_start = event.pos[0]
134        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP:
135            super().unSelect()
136        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEMOTION:
137            if super().isSelected():
138                self.scroller_pos = self.def_scroller_pos + (event.pos[0] - self.drag_start)
139                self.scroller_pos = min(
140                    max(0, self.scroller_pos), super().getWidth() - self.scroller_size)
141                if self.callback is not None:
142                    self.callback(self.scroller_pos / (super().getWidth() - self.scroller_size))
143
144    @overrides(GUIElement)
145    def update(self, view):
146        """
147        Update logic for the scrollbar.
148
149        This method is a placeholder for future extensions; currently, it does not perform any updates.
150
151        Args:
152            view: The parent View instance.
153        """
154        pass

  • scroller_pos (int): Current X position (in pixels) of the scroller.
  • scroller_size (int): Width of the draggable scroller in pixels.

class VerticalScrollbar(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class VerticalScrollbar(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents a vertical scrollbar UI element for SUILib applications.
 44
 45    The VerticalScrollbar allows users to scroll through a content area by dragging
 46    the scroller handle. It supports custom styles, event callbacks, and integrates
 47    with the View layout system.
 48
 49    Attributes:
 50        scroller_pos (float): Current vertical position of the scroller handle.
 51        scroller_size (int): Height of the scroller handle in pixels.
 52        callback (callable): Function to call when the scroller is moved.
 53    """
 54
 55    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, scroller_size: int, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 56        """
 57        Initialize a new VerticalScrollbar.
 58
 59        Args:
 60            view: The parent View instance where this scrollbar is placed.
 61            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the scrollbar.
 62                See config/styles.json for details.
 63            scroller_size (int): Height of the scroller handle in pixels.
 64            width (int, optional): Width of the scrollbar in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 65            height (int, optional): Height of the scrollbar in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 66            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the scrollbar. Defaults to 0.
 67            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the scrollbar. Defaults to 0.
 68        """
 69        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style, pygame.SYSTEM_CURSOR_SIZENS)
 70        self.callback = None
 71        self.scroller_pos = 0
 72        self.scroller_size = scroller_size
 73
 74    def setScrollerSize(self, size: int):
 75        """
 76        Set the size of the scroller handle.
 77
 78        Args:
 79            size (int): New height of the scroller handle in pixels.
 80        """
 81        self.scroller_size = max(size, super().getWidth())
 82
 83    def setOnScrollEvt(self, callback):
 84        """
 85        Set a callback to be called when the scrollbar is scrolled.
 86
 87        Args:
 88            callback (callable): Function to be called with the new position (0.0 - 1.0).
 89        """
 90        self.callback = callback
 91
 92    @overrides(GUIElement)
 93    def draw(self, view, screen):
 94        """
 95        Render the scrollbar background, handle, and outline.
 96
 97        Args:
 98            view: The parent View instance.
 99            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the scrollbar onto.
100        """
101        # Background
102        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect())
103        # Scroller handle
104        pygame.draw.rect(
105            screen,
106            super().getStyle()["foreground_color"],
107            pygame.Rect(
108                super().getX(),
109                super().getY() + self.scroller_pos,
110                super().getWidth(),
111                self.scroller_size
112            ),
113            border_radius=6
114        )
115        # Outline
116        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2)
117
118    @overrides(GUIElement)
119    def processEvent(self, view, event):
120        """
121        Handle Pygame events for scrollbar interaction (dragging the handle).
122
123        Args:
124            view: The parent View instance.
125            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
126        """
127        if self.scroller_size >= super().getHeight():
128            return
129        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
130            if inRect(event.pos[0], event.pos[1], super().getViewRect()):
131                super().select()
132                self.def_scroller_pos = self.scroller_pos
133                self.drag_start = event.pos[1]
134        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP:
135            super().unSelect()
136        elif event.type == pygame.MOUSEMOTION:
137            if super().isSelected():
138                self.scroller_pos = self.def_scroller_pos + (event.pos[1] - self.drag_start)
139                self.scroller_pos = min(
140                    max(0, self.scroller_pos), super().getHeight() - self.scroller_size)
141                if self.callback is not None:
142                    self.callback(self.scroller_pos / (super().getHeight() - self.scroller_size))
143
144    @overrides(GUIElement)
145    def update(self, view):
146        """
147        Update logic for the vertical scrollbar.
148
149        Args:
150            view: The parent View instance.
151        """
152        pass

The VerticalScrollbar allows users to scroll through a content area by dragging the scroller handle. It supports custom styles, event callbacks, and integrates with the View layout system.

Attributes:
  • scroller_pos (float): Current vertical position of the scroller handle.
  • scroller_size (int): Height of the scroller handle in pixels.
  • callback (callable): Function to call when the scroller is moved.

class Image(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class Image(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents an image UI element for SUILib applications.
 44
 45    The Image element displays a bitmap loaded from a file path, scaled to fit its assigned area.
 46    It supports dynamic image changes, integrates with the View layout system, and can be used
 47    for static icons, previews, or general-purpose image display within the UI.
 48
 49    Attributes:
 50        image (pygame.Surface): The currently loaded image surface.
 51    """
 52
 53    def __init__(self, view, image_path: str, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 54        """
 55        Initialize a new Image element.
 56
 57        Args:
 58            view: The parent View instance where this image is placed.
 59            image_path (str): The file path to the image to display.
 60            width (int, optional): Width of the image area in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 61            height (int, optional): Height of the image area in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 62            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the image. Defaults to 0.
 63            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the image. Defaults to 0.
 64        """
 65        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, None)
 66        self.image = loadImage(image_path)
 67
 68    def setImage(self, image_path: str):
 69        """
 70        Set a new image to be displayed.
 71
 72        Args:
 73            image_path (str): The file path to the new image.
 74        """
 75        self.image = loadImage(image_path)
 76
 77    def getImage(self) -> pygame.Surface:
 78        """
 79        Get the currently loaded image surface.
 80
 81        Returns:
 82            pygame.Surface: The current image surface, or None if not loaded.
 83        """
 84        return self.image
 85
 86    @overrides(GUIElement)
 87    def draw(self, view, screen):
 88        """
 89        Render the image onto the given Pygame surface, scaled to fit the element's area.
 90
 91        Args:
 92            view: The parent View instance.
 93            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the image onto.
 94        """
 95        if self.image is not None:
 96            screen.blit(
 97                pygame.transform.scale(self.image, (super().getWidth(), super().getHeight())),
 98                (super().getX(), super().getY())
 99            )

109        """
110        pass

114        """
115        Update logic for the image element.
116
117        Args:
118            view: The parent View instance.
119        """
120        pass

class Label(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement): 
 41class Label(GUIElement):
 42    """
 43    Represents a static text label UI element for SUILib applications.
 44
 45    The Label displays a single line of text, optionally aligned horizontally and/or vertically
 46    relative to its coordinates. It supports custom styles, font settings, and integrates with
 47    the View layout system. Labels are typically used as captions, titles, or static annotations
 48    within the interface.
 49
 50    Attributes:
 51        text (str): The text content displayed by the label.
 52        h_centered (bool): Whether the text is horizontally centered.
 53        v_centered (bool): Whether the text is vertically centered.
 54        font (pygame.font.Font): Font object used for rendering the label text.
 55    """
 56
 57    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, text: str, h_centered: bool = False, v_centered: bool = False, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 58        """
 59        Initialize a new Label element.
 60
 61        Args:
 62            view: The parent View instance where this label is placed.
 63            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the label.
 64                See config/styles.json for details.
 65            text (str): The text to display on the label.
 66            h_centered (bool, optional): If True, center text horizontally. Defaults to False.
 67            v_centered (bool, optional): If True, center text vertically. Defaults to False.
 68            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the label. Defaults to 0.
 69            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the label. Defaults to 0.
 70        """
 71        super().__init__(view, x, y, 0, 0, style)
 72        self.text = text
 73        self.h_centered = h_centered
 74        self.v_centered = v_centered
 75        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
 76            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
 77            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
 78            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
 79        )
 80
 81    def setHCentered(self, centered: bool):
 82        """
 83        Set horizontal alignment for the label text.
 84
 85        Args:
 86            centered (bool): If True, text will be horizontally centered at the label's X coordinate.
 87        """
 88        self.h_centered = centered
 89
 90    def setVCentered(self, centered: bool):
 91        """
 92        Set vertical alignment for the label text.
 93
 94        Args:
 95            centered (bool): If True, text will be vertically centered at the label's Y coordinate.
 96        """
 97        self.v_centered = centered
 98
 99    def setText(self, text: str):
100        """
101        Set the text displayed by the label.
102
103        Args:
104            text (str): New label text.
105        """
106        self.text = text
107
108    def getText(self) -> str:
109        """
110        Get the current text content of the label.
111
112        Returns:
113            str: The label's text.
114        """
115        return self.text
116
117    @overrides(GUIElement)
118    def draw(self, view, screen):
119        """
120        Render the label's text onto the given Pygame surface.
121
122        Args:
123            view: The parent View instance.
124            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the label onto.
125        """
126        if len(self.text) != 0:
127            text_surface = self.font.render(self.text, True, super().getStyle()["foreground_color"])
128            x = super().getX()
129            if self.h_centered:
130                x -= text_surface.get_width() / 2
131            y = super().getY()
132            if self.v_centered:
133                y -= text_surface.get_height() / 2
134            screen.blit(text_surface, (x, y))
135
136    @overrides(GUIElement)
137    def processEvent(self, view, event):
138        """
139        Process Pygame events for the label (labels are static and do not handle events).
140
141        Args:
142            view: The parent View instance.
143            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
144        """
145        pass
146
147    @overrides(GUIElement)
148    def update(self, view):
149        """
150        Update logic for the label (labels are static and do not require updates).
151
152        Args:
153            view: The parent View instance.
154        """
155        pass

class ListPanel(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement, SUILib.guielement.Container): 
 43class ListPanel(GUIElement, Container):
 44    """
 45    Represents a scrollable list panel UI element for SUILib applications.
 46
 47    The ListPanel displays a vertical list of string items, supporting scrolling via an integrated
 48    vertical scrollbar. It provides click callbacks for item selection, dynamic list refresh,
 49    and can be used as a dropdown menu, selection panel, or general-purpose list container.
 50
 51    Attributes:
 52        data (list): List of string items to display.
 53        v_scroll (VerticalScrollbar): Scrollbar for vertical navigation.
 54        body_offset_y (float): Current vertical offset for list rendering.
 55        font (pygame.font.Font): Font object used for rendering list items.
 56        callback (callable): Function to be called when an item is clicked.
 57        layoutmanager: Reserved for future custom layout integration.
 58    """
 59
 60    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, data: list, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 61        """
 62        Initialize a new ListPanel instance.
 63
 64        Args:
 65            view: The parent View instance where this panel is placed.
 66            style (dict): Dictionary describing the style for this panel.
 67                See config/styles.json for details.
 68            data (list): List of string items to display in the panel.
 69            width (int, optional): Width of the panel in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 70            height (int, optional): Height of the panel in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 71            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the panel. Defaults to 0.
 72            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the panel. Defaults to 0.
 73        """
 74        self.data = data
 75        self.v_scroll = None
 76        self.body_offset_y = 0
 77        super().__init__(view, x, y, width, height, style)
 78        self.v_scroll = VerticalScrollbar(
 79            view, super().getStyle()["scrollbar"], super().getStyle()["scrollbar_width"])
 80        self.v_scroll.setOnScrollEvt(self.scrollVertical)
 81        self.layoutmanager = None
 82        self.callback = None
 83        self.refreshList()
 84
 85    @overrides(GUIElement)
 86    def updateViewRect(self):
 87        """
 88        Update the ListPanel's view rectangle and refresh layout and scrollbar.
 89        """
 90        super().updateViewRect()
 91        self.refreshList()
 92
 93    def setItemClickEvet(self, callback):
 94        """
 95        Set the callback function to be called when a list item is clicked.
 96
 97        Args:
 98            callback (callable): Function to be called with the clicked item's value.
 99        """
100        self.callback = callback
101
102    def scrollVertical(self, position: float):
103        """
104        Event handler for vertical scrollbar movement.
105
106        Args:
107            position (float): Vertical scroll position in the range [0.0, 1.0].
108        """
109        total_body_data_height = 10 + (self.font.get_height() + 10) * len(self.data)
110        h = super().getHeight()
111        self.body_offset_y = -max(0, (total_body_data_height - h)) * position
112
113    def refreshList(self, new_data: list = None):
114        """
115        Refresh or update the contents of the list panel.
116
117        Args:
118            new_data (list, optional): New list of string items to display.
119                If None, refreshes with current data.
120        """
121        if new_data is not None:
122            self.data = new_data
123
124        self.font = pygame.font.SysFont(
125            super().getStyle()["font_name"],
126            super().getStyle()["font_size"],
127            bold=super().getStyle()["font_bold"]
128        )
129        self.height = 10 + (self.font.get_height() + 10) * min(5, len(self.data))
130
131        if self.v_scroll is not None:
132            sw = super().getStyle()["scrollbar_width"]
133            self.v_scroll.setX(super().getX() + super().getWidth() - sw)
134            self.v_scroll.setY(super().getY())
135            self.v_scroll.setWidth(sw)
136            self.v_scroll.setHeight(super().getHeight())
137
138            height = 10 + (self.font.get_height() + 10) * len(self.data)
139            self.v_scroll.setScrollerSize(
140                (1.0 - max(0, height - super().getHeight()) / height) * self.v_scroll.getHeight()
141            )
142
143    @overrides(GUIElement)
144    def draw(self, view, screen):
145        """
146        Render the list panel, including background, visible items, scrollbar, and outline.
147
148        Args:
149            view: The parent View instance.
150            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the panel onto.
151        """
152        # Draw background
153        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect(), border_radius=5)
154
155        # Draw list items
156        if len(self.data) != 0:
157            screen.set_clip(super().getViewRect())
158            offset = super().getY() + 10 + self.body_offset_y
159            for line in self.data:
160                text = self.font.render(
161                    line, 1, super().getStyle()["foreground_color"])
162                screen.blit(text, (super().getX() + 10, offset))
163                offset += text.get_height() + 10
164            screen.set_clip(None)
165
166        # Draw vertical scrollbar
167        self.v_scroll.draw(view, screen)
168
169        # Draw outline
170        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2, border_radius=5)
171
172    @overrides(GUIElement)
173    def processEvent(self, view, event):
174        """
175        Handle Pygame events for list item selection and scrollbar interaction.
176
177        Args:
178            view: The parent View instance.
179            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
180        """
181        self.v_scroll.processEvent(view, event)
182
183        if event.type == pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN:
184            offset = super().getY() + 10 + self.body_offset_y
185            for line in self.data:
186                if inRect(
187                        event.pos[0],
188                        event.pos[1],
189                        pygame.Rect(
190                            super().getX(),
191                            offset,
192                            super().getWidth() - self.v_scroll.getWidth() - 5,
193                            self.font.get_height()
194                        )):
195                    if self.callback is not None:
196                        self.callback(line)
197                offset += self.font.get_height() + 10
198
199    @overrides(GUIElement)
200    def update(self, view):
201        """
202        Update logic for the list panel.
203
204        This method is a placeholder for future extensions; currently, it does not perform any updates.
205
206        Args:
207            view: The parent View instance.
208        """
209        pass
210
211    @overrides(Container)
212    def getChilds(self):
213        """
214        Return the child elements of the ListPanel.
215
216        Returns:
217            list: List containing the vertical scrollbar as a child element.
218        """
219        return [self.v_scroll]

Represents a scrollable list panel UI element for SUILib applications.

The ListPanel displays a vertical list of string items, supporting scrolling via an integrated vertical scrollbar. It provides click callbacks for item selection, dynamic list refresh, and can be used as a dropdown menu, selection panel, or general-purpose list container.

Attributes:
  • data (list): List of string items to display.
  • v_scroll (VerticalScrollbar): Scrollbar for vertical navigation.
  • body_offset_y (float): Current vertical offset for list rendering.
  • font (pygame.font.Font): Font object used for rendering list items.
  • callback (callable): Function to be called when an item is clicked.
  • layoutmanager: Reserved for future custom layout integration.

class Panel(SUILib.guielement.GUIElement, SUILib.application.Layout, SUILib.guielement.Container): 
 42class Panel(GUIElement, Layout, Container):
 43    """
 44    Represents a container panel UI element for SUILib applications.
 45
 46    The Panel serves as a flexible container for layout of multiple child elements. It supports
 47    custom layout managers, background and outline rendering, and event delegation to contained elements.
 48    Panels are typically used to organize groups of controls or visual content within an interface.
 49
 50    Attributes:
 51        layoutmanager (Layout): The layout manager controlling arrangement of child elements.
 52    """
 53
 54    def __init__(self, view, style: dict, width: int = 0, height: int = 0, x: int = 0, y: int = 0):
 55        """
 56        Initialize a new Panel element.
 57
 58        Args:
 59            view: The parent View instance where this panel is placed.
 60            style (dict): Dictionary containing style attributes for the panel.
 61                See config/styles.json for details.
 62            width (int, optional): Width of the panel in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 63            height (int, optional): Height of the panel in pixels. Defaults to 0.
 64            x (int, optional): X coordinate of the panel. Defaults to 0.
 65            y (int, optional): Y coordinate of the panel. Defaults to 0.
 66        """
 67        GUIElement.__init__(self, view, x, y, width, height, style)
 68        Layout.__init__(self, view)
 69        self.layoutmanager = None
 70
 71    def setLayoutManager(self, layoutmanager: Layout):
 72        """
 73        Set the layout manager for arranging elements inside the panel.
 74
 75        Args:
 76            layoutmanager (Layout): The layout manager instance.
 77        """
 78        self.layoutmanager = layoutmanager
 79        self.getView().unregisterLayoutManager(self.layoutmanager)
 80
 81    @overrides(GUIElement)
 82    def draw(self, view, screen):
 83        """
 84        Render the panel background, contained elements, and outline.
 85
 86        Args:
 87            view: The parent View instance.
 88            screen (pygame.Surface): The surface to render the panel onto.
 89        """
 90        # Draw background
 91        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["background_color"], super().getViewRect(), border_radius=5)
 92
 93        # Draw child elements within panel area
 94        if len(self.getLayoutElements()) != 0:
 95            panel_screen = screen.subsurface(
 96                pygame.Rect(
 97                    super().getX() + 5,
 98                    super().getY() + 5,
 99                    min(max(super().getWidth() - 10, 10), screen.get_width() - super().getX() - 5),
100                    min(max(super().getHeight() - 10, 10), screen.get_height() - super().getY() - 5)
101                )
102            )
103            for el in self.getLayoutElements():
104                el["element"].draw(view, panel_screen)
105
106        # Draw outline
107        pygame.draw.rect(screen, super().getStyle()["outline_color"], super().getViewRect(), 2, border_radius=5)
108
109    @overrides(GUIElement)
110    def processEvent(self, view, event):
111        """
112        Handle Pygame events for panel and delegate to child elements.
113
114        Args:
115            view: The parent View instance.
116            event (pygame.event.Event): The event to process.
117        """
118        if len(self.getLayoutElements()) != 0:
119            panel_evt = event
120
121            # Offset event position for child elements
122            if panel_evt.type in (pygame.MOUSEMOTION, pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP, pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN):
123                panel_evt.pos = (
124                    panel_evt.pos[0] - super().getX(),
125                    panel_evt.pos[1] - super().getY()
126                )
127
128            # Propagate event to each child element
129            for el in self.getLayoutElements():
130                el["element"].processEvent(view, panel_evt)
131
132            # Restore event position
133            if panel_evt.type in (pygame.MOUSEMOTION, pygame.MOUSEBUTTONUP, pygame.MOUSEBUTTONDOWN):
134                panel_evt.pos = (
135                    panel_evt.pos[0] + super().getX(),
136                    panel_evt.pos[1] + super().getY()
137                )
138
139    @overrides(GUIElement)
140    def update(self, view):
141        """
142        Update logic for the panel and all contained elements.
143
144        Args:
145            view: The parent View instance.
146        """
147        for el in self.getLayoutElements():
148            el["element"].update(view)
149
150    @overrides(Layout)
151    def updateLayout(self, width, height):
152        """
153        Update the layout of the panel's child elements using its layout manager.
154
155        Args:
156            width (int): New width for the layout area.
157            height (int): New height for the layout area.
158        """
159        if self.layoutmanager is not None:
160            self.layoutmanager.setElements(self.getLayoutElements())
161            self.layoutmanager.updateLayout(
162                self.getWidth() - 10, self.getHeight() - 10
163            )
164
165    @overrides(Container)
166    def getChilds(self):
167        """
168        Return the child elements of the panel.
169
170        Returns:
171            list: List of contained GUI elements.
172        """
173        elements = []
174        for le in self.getLayoutElements():
175            elements.append(le["element"])
176        return elements

141        """
142        Update logic for the panel and all contained elements.
143
144        Args:
145            view: The parent View instance.
146        """
147        for el in self.getLayoutElements():
148            el["element"].update(view)
